newsitem.title: USA: Triton finds 5th Thai Gulf field.
newsitem.headline: Triton finds 5th Thai Gulf field.

text.p: Triton Energy Ltd said Monday it has again discovered both oil and natural gas on Block A-18 in the Gulf of Thailand.

The Senja Field is the fifth field found by Triton on the block since exploratory drilling began in the area in 1995, the company said. It has a 50 percent working interest there, as does Petronas Carigali (JDA) Sdn. Bhd, an exploration and production subsidiary of Malaysian state oil firm Petronas.
On test, the Senja-1 exploratory well flowed at a combined daily rate of 2,725 barrels of oil, 39 million cubic feet of gas and 368 barrels of condensate from selected intervals.
The find is located in the northwest corner of Block A-18.

"Senja-1 is the first well drilled on an entirely new play fairway on the block," said Al Turner, Triton senior vice president, operations. "We are pleased about discovering oil and gas in this location."

The well was flow tested from four intervals between 4,756 and 6,986 feet through choke sizes ranging from 24/64-inch to two inches. Flowing tubing pressure was between 409 and 2,209 pounds per square inch, Triton said.
The oil was 37-46 degrees gravity, and the condensate was 44-45 degrees gravity.
The Senja-1 was drilled in about 179 feet of water to a depth of 7,600 feet.

During 1997, Triton said, it plans to drill additional exploratory wells on the block, as well as appraise and delineate the Bumi Field. The rig that drilled the Senja-1 well will move east of the Bumi Field to drill an exploratory well on another untested prospect.
